Kosaraju's Strongly Connected Components Algorithm

Let be a graph with vertices and edges.

is strongly connected if for all in :
(1) There is a path from to .
(2) There is a path from to .

Based on this definition, we can decompose a graph into strongly connected components. To find these strongly connected components, we describe Kosaraju’s amazing algorithm.

Algorithm


Example

Let’s apply Kosaraju’s algorithm on the above graph. First we need to run DFS while keeping tracking of the finishing times of vertices. We start by visiting and mark the start time as 0. We will continue to visit and then marking their start times below. Now doesn’t have any more neighbors to visit and so we mark it as finished with finish time = 3. We then visit and and mark them as finished when there are no more neighbors to visit. Below is the result so far. Next we see that is finished and we return to but doesn’t have more neighbors and so we mark it finished as well. We finally visit and mark it as finished as well. Great! Now we run the second step of Kosaraju’s algorithm and reverse all the edges in . Now to the last step of running a second pass of dfs in the reversed graph starting with the node with the largest finishing time. We therefore start with . We notice that can’t reach any vertices and so is the first strongly connected component! We next visit , and and that’s our second strongly connected component. We finally visit and and that’s our third and final strongly connected component as expected.

Correctness Proof

Why does this algorithm find the SCCs? To show how, we’ll first prove two important lemmas that we’ll use in proving that the algorithm is correct.

Lemma 1: The SCC graph is a DAG

Proof: Suppose that the SCC graph is not a DAG and let and be two components where there is an edge from to and an edge from to . Let be a vertex in and let be a vertex in . By the connected component definition, we know there is a path between and every vertex in . Similarly, there is a path between and any vertex in . Since there is an edge from to then there is a path from to any vertex in and Similarly, there is a path between and any vertex in . Therefore, the vertices in and must be in the same strongly connected component. This is a contradiction, since we assumed and two strongly connected components. Therefore, the SCC graph must be a DAG.

Lemma 2: In the SCC DAG, if there is an edge from component to component then

Proof: There are two cases:
Case 1: We reached before in our first DFS:
Let have the largest finish time in and have the largest finish time in . Let be the first node discovered in then we will reach and discover then at some point we will reach and discover . This means that is a descendant of . By the parentheses theorem, this means that has a larger finish time. Since has the largest finish time in , then and since then we have , as required.


Case 2: We reached before in our first DFS:
Since we assumed that there is an edge from to then by Lemma 1, we don’t have an edge from to .Therefore, we will explore completely first and then will be explored later after we restart the DFS, this means that , as we wanted to show.

Corollary 1: In the SCC DAG, if there is an edge from component to component in the reversed graph, then

We can now combine the previous results to prove the following theorem:

Theorem: The algorithm we saw before will correctly identify strongly connected components

Proof:
Inductive Hypothesis: The first trees found in the second (reversed) DFS forest are the SCCs with the largest finish times. Moreover, what’s left unvisited after these trees have been explored is a DAG on the un-found SCCs.

Base Case: It is vacuously true that the first 0 trees found in the reversed DFS forest are the 0 SCCs with the largest finish times. Moreover, what’s left unvisited after 0 trees have been explored is a DAG on all the SCCs by Lemma 1.

Inductive Step: Assume by induction that the first trees are the last-finishing SCCs, and the remaining SCCs form a DAG.
Now, consider the st tree produced and let be the root of the tree. Let be in SCC . We know that for the remaining SCCs . This is because we chose in the second DFS to have the largest finish time.
Also since , then there are no edges going from to because suppose there was an edge to some component then by Corollary 1 which is a contradiction since has the largest finish time.
Therefore, we will only discover vertices in in the second DFS started from . So the st tree is the SCC with the (t+1)st biggest finish time. Also the remaining SCCs still form a DAG, since removing a vertex won’t create a cycle.

Conclusion: The second (reversed) DFS forest contains all the SCCs as its trees.

Running Time

What are we doing in this algorithm algorithm? Two passes of DFS that we know run in . Therefore, the running time is astonishingly .
